sen.j: 久米御縣神社（くめのみあがたじんじゃ）は、奈良県橿原市にある神社である。
sen.e: Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine is located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine is located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine is located in Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は村社。
sen.e: It was a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and was categorized as a sonsha (a village shrine) in the old shrine ranking.
It was a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in ancient Engishiki laws) and was categorized as a sonsha (a village shrine) in the old shrine ranking.
It was a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in ancient Engishiki laws) and was categorized as a sonsha (a village shrine) in the old shrine ranking.
Enshrined Deity
Enshrined Deity
Enshrined Deity

sen.j: タカミムスビ・大来目命（天久米命）・天櫛根命を祀る。
sen.e: The shrine enshrines Takamimusubi, Okunome no mikoto (Amatsukume no mikoto) and Amanokushine no mikoto.
The shrine enshrines Takamimusubi, Okunome no mikoto (Amatsukume no mikoto) and Amanokushine no mikoto.
The shrine enshrines Takamimusubi, Okunome no mikoto (Amatsukume no mikoto) and Amanokushine no mikoto.

sen.j: 『五郡神社記』では「天櫛根大久米命」で一つの神名とされていた。
sen.e: According to the "Gogun Jinja-ki" (Record of Shrines in Five Counties), the name of the god is referred to as 'Amatsukume-Okunome no mikoto'.
sen.cmt: 天櫛根大久米命：定訳不明五郡神社記:定訳不明一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the "Gogun Jinja-ki" (Record of Shrines in Five Counties), the god is referred to with the name 'Amatsukume-Okunome no mikoto'.
sen.cmt: ACcording to > in. the name of the god > the god...with the name.
sen.e: In the "Gogun Jinja-ki" (Record of Shrines in Five Counties), the god is referred to with the name 'Amatsukume-Okunome no mikoto'.

sen.j: しかし、『式内社調査報告』では、元は一柱の神であったものが近世に2つに分割して伝えられたものであると考えられるとしている。
sen.e: However, in the "Shikinai-sha Chosa Hokoku-sho" (Shikinai-sha Survey Report), it is believed that the god was divided into two gods in recent history.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in the "Shikinai-sha Chosa Hokoku-sho" (Shikinai-sha Survey Report), it is believed that although originally one god, it was divided into two in recent times.
However, in the "Shikinai-sha Chosa Hokoku-sho" (Shikinai-sha Survey Report), it is believed that although originally one god, it was divided into two in recent times.

sen.j: 大来目命は久米部の祖神である。
sen.e: Okunome no mikoto is a soshin (an ancestor honored as god) of Kumebe.
Okunome no mikoto is a soshin (an ancestor honored as god) of Kumebe.
Okunome no mikoto is a soshin (an ancestor honored as god) of Kumebe.

sen.j: 一帯は久米部の居住地であった来目邑であり、その祖神を祀ったものである。
sen.e: The area (Kurumemura Village) where Kumebe used to live also houses the shrine where Kumebe's ancestors are enshrined.
The area (Kurumemura Village) where Kumebe used to live also houses the shrine where Kumebe's ancestors are enshrined.
The area (Kurumemura Village) where Kumebe used to live also houses the shrine where Kumebe's ancestors are enshrined.
History
History
History

sen.j: 創建の由緒は不詳である。
sen.e: The history of its foundation is unknown.
The history of its foundation is unknown.
The history of its foundation is unknown.

sen.j: 「御県神社」という神社は大和国内に7社あり、いずれも皇室の御料地である御県（みあがた）に鎮座していたものである。
sen.e: There were seven shrines called 'Miagata-jinja Shrine' in Yamato Province, and all of them were enshrined in Miagata as goryochi (Imperial estates).
There were seven shrines called 'Miagata-jinja Shrine' in Yamato Province, and all of them were enshrined in Miagata as goryochi (Imperial estates).
There were seven shrines called 'Miagata-jinja Shrine' in Yamato Province, and all of them were enshrined in Miagata as goryochi (Imperial estates).

sen.j: 『日本書紀』垂仁天皇27年に「是歳、来目邑に屯倉を興す」という記述があり、創建もその頃とみられる。
sen.e: Since there was a description written in 3 B.C. in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) saying that 'Miyake (Imperial-controlled territory) was founded in Kurumemura Village that year', the shrine is thought to have been founded around the time.

Since there is a passage in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) written in 3 B.C. saying that 'Miyake (Imperial-controlled territory) was founded in Kurumemura Village that year', the shrine is thought to have been founded at around that time.
sen.cmt: description > passage. around that time > at around that time.
sen.e: Since there is a passage in the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) written in 3 B.C. saying that 'Miyake (Imperial-controlled territory) was founded in Kurumemura Village that year', the shrine is thought to have been founded at around that time.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では「大和国高市郡 久米御縣神社三座」と記載され、小社に列格している。
sen.e: It is listed as a 'Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine Sanza in Takaichi-gun, Yamato Province' in the Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) and is categorized as a small shrine.
It is listed as a 'Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine Sanza in Takaichi-gun, Yamato Province' in the Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) and is categorized as a small shrine.
It is listed as a 'Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine Sanza in Takaichi-gun, Yamato Province' in the Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) and is categorized as a small shrine.

sen.j: ただし、延喜式祈年祝詞には他の6つの御県神社が記載されているが、当社は含まれていない。
sen.e: Although all the other six Miagata-jinja Shrines are listed in the Engishiki Kinen Norito (Engishiki Kinen Shinto prayer), Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine is not listed.
sen.cmt: 延喜式祈年祝詞:定訳不明
sen.e: Although all the other six Miagata-jinja Shrines are listed in the Engishiki Kinen Norito (Prayer for Good Harvests), Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine is not listed.
sen.cmt: kinen shinto prayer > prayer for good harvests.
sen.e: Although all the other six Miagata-jinja Shrines are listed in the Engishiki Kinen Norito (Prayer for Good Harvests), Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine is not listed.

sen.j: 久米氏の衰退とともに当社も衰微した。
sen.e: As the Kume clan declined, the shrine also declined.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: With the fall of the Kume clan, the shrine also fell into decline.
sen.cmt: as the > with the. decline > fell into decline.
sen.e: With the fall of the Kume clan, the shrine also fell into decline.

sen.j: しかし、隣接して久米寺が創建され、当社はその鎮守社として再建された。
sen.e: However, the shrine was later reconstructed as a chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on Buddhist temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area) when Kume-dera Temple was founded next to it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, when Kume-dera Temple was founded next to the shrine, it was later reconstructed as a Chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area).
However, when Kume-dera Temple was founded next to the shrine, it was later reconstructed as a Chinju-sha shrine (Shinto shrine on temple grounds dedicated to the tutelary deity of the area).

sen.j: 江戸時代中期頃からは「天満宮」「天神社」と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: It started to be referred to as 'Tenman-gu Shrine' or 'Ten-jinja Shrine' from the mid Edo period.
It started to be referred to as 'Tenman-gu Shrine' or 'Ten-jinja Shrine' from the mid Edo period.
It started to be referred to as 'Tenman-gu Shrine' or 'Ten-jinja Shrine' from the mid Edo period.

sen.j: 現在も、「天満宮」「天神社」と書かれた燈籠が数多く残る。
sen.e: Today, many stone lanterns inscribed with 'Tenman-gu Shrine' or 'Ten-jinja Shrine' remain.
Today, many stone lanterns inscribed with 'Tenman-gu Shrine' or 'Ten-jinja Shrine' remain.
Today, many stone lanterns inscribed with 'Tenman-gu Shrine' or 'Ten-jinja Shrine' remain.

sen.j: 明治初年の神仏分離により久米寺から分離され、明治中期に久米御縣神社に改称した。
sen.e: When Buddhism and Shintoism split in 1868, the shrine separated from Kume-dera Temple and the name was changed to Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine in the mid Meiji period.
When Buddhism and Shintoism split in 1868, the shrine separated from Kume-dera Temple and the name was changed to Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine in the mid Meiji period.
When Buddhism and Shintoism split in 1868, the shrine separated from Kume-dera Temple and the name was changed to Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine in the mid Meiji period.
